title: 6th sense in league
body:
So nowdays when I play a game I usually have a friend play wingman who tells me exactly what will work in certain situations (if im at half heath but ahed and I see the enemy carry following me, he will tell me if I can do it where I just think I can't).

When to take a camp before recalling, best times to buy certain items against certain matchups (who is fed, what works against them although I can do that on my own a lot too).

Most importantly he knows the balance of my damage across my abilities and items so he knows that the most damaging wont work against certain champions in order to kill them whereas other stuff might.

I know this is basic knowledge for good players but I struggle sometimes with this and I'm wondering what is the fastest way to learn this "meta knowledge" without constant grinding/ trail and error.

replies.body: Well to be completely honest with you, playing the game and experience is the only way to really learn this stuff. Most of what you said in your post will come with experience of your champion.

> [{quoted}](name=DiamondAries,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=6RLKVczt,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2015-06-04T01:03:49.393+0000)
>
> Well to be completely honest with you, playing the game and experience is the only way to really learn this stuff. Most of what you said in your post will come with experience of your champion.

How long did it take you? I'll admit this post was for Rengar and I have played him for approximately 2 months now but from what you have said it seems it might be longer until I get the hang of it

2 months? It shouldn't take that long. Maybe you are going about it the wrong way. Try looking up videos on YouTube about Rengar, or pro games where they play Rengar. That might help. Also, look up some guides on MobaFire or the like and you might learn something new there.

In general, just do some research. That's how I usually learn new things.

If it is a specific champion you are looking to master, i'd recommend you really study it's stats/numbers. But as Aries said above, these things come through experience and practice. It's very important that you don't over play the champion, this may cause you to get bored and make poor decisions resulting in a bad plays, pushing to deep due to thinking you're more powerful and strong then you really are, or being a little to passive because you underestimate yourself.

I'd say you should just test out different builds with Rengar, different strategies, routes etc. but remember not to grind him or you'll get bored, and in time you'll naturally know his strengths and what situations you're best in.
IMO 50-100 games is how many you need to get that 6th sense for a specific champion.

> [{quoted}](name=Maraudaur,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=6RLKVczt,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2015-06-04T02:27:50.011+0000)
>
> IMO 50-100 games is how many you need to get that 6th sense for a specific champion.

I think it really depends on the player as well though... some may take less or more. But it really is just about testing and experience.
Yeah agreed! but I reckon even the best players need 25+ games to build those inherent "instincts" that come from experiencing a majority of match ups and situations.

I think it's more a matter of how aggresive your willing to go in those games, sure mastering a champion will take longer, but getting a handle over their damage doesn't take as long (which is the 6th sense being talked about)

Realistically if your focusing mainly on getting that factor, it may only take a dozen or so games to get a handle on knowing your damage against a full squishy or a tank at every stage of the game (depending on how long your games go, you may not learn the end game damage as early.).

I agree getting a grasp on the instinct for only damage output may take less than 50-100 games (maybe 35 for a player who plays quite aggressively). I agree playing more aggressive lets you learn your limits faster. However a dozen is a bit low, not only do you need to understand how much damage your abilities do, but you also need to take into account the following details and to know all of the below instinctively it takes wayyyyy more games even if you play HAM every game.

* Cooldowns
* Ability order
* Target Champions base stats
* Target Champions items
* Your own Items
* Are you ahead
* Are you behind
* do they have Movement speed on you
* do they have abilities that can block/avoid yours
* Target Champions abilities
* Target Champions cooldowns

These were just off the top of my head. But as you can see to fully understand at an instinct level a certain champions damage output in all the possible different situations in League of Legends means you need a lot of experience against a lot of different champions under a lot of different circumstances.

However damage output isn't the only instinct required to master a champion. The 6th sense Chicken4dinner was talking about isn't just about damage, but also cooldowns, movement speed, enemy positioning (when you can and cant take a camp before recalling), vision control (glance at the map and know if you're safe or not). This is why I think mastery a champing on an instinct level takes 50-100 games.

But I cant talk for Chicken4dinner, I assume he meant all aspects of instinct and not just damage

Maybe i'm a different type of player, i can generally get a champion down in very few games (i wouldn't by any means say mastered, but knowing the champion itself.)

Sure different champions have different base armor/magic resist but generally depending on the time of the game (and of course their items) you can generally have a decent idea of your damage.

Also for the taking camps etc. i think that's more common knowledge even then actual champion knowledge (unless your on a really low damage champion)

Sure there are a lot of factors to take into consideration, but i feel you can have a decent knowledge of a champion after about a dozen games, by no means mastered, but you should have a good understanding of them none the less.

The biggest thing i'd say that comes from mastering over just knowing a champion, is knowing your limits when your behind over when your ahead.

Also then again i'm an analytical sort of guy that knows most champions fairly decently whether i have played them or not, so maybe i just have way too much knowledge for this to be relatable.

Maybe you get the instincts faster than most! But that's extremely rare, I've played over 50 games with Xerath (climbed to Diamond with him now yay!) But to be honest there are still many match ups and situations that I haven't encountered. 

I know him relatively well and have instincts built in in certain match ups now (I would like to think) . But there is still so much for me to learn, so many champion match ups are still difficult for me and all the specific ability travel speeds I haven't got down on instinct yet.

I honestly believe to get a champion down to instinct takes more than 50 games. But maybe I am misunderstanding what Chicken4dinner meant. 

If we are just talking about general damage, and vaguely knowing how strong you are then sure 15~ games is more than enough. But to have a champion down to instincts to me is something much more than that and a lot closer to mastering it than just understanding damage output.

Hey marauder, I love the discussion this has sparked but I need to clarify something.

The knowledge of damage bases on a champion was indeed the **example** given but as you suggested earlier by no means the only reason why I am asking for help.

If I needed to know just damage I would spend 20 minutes in the wiki going over a champion and all of his stats, scalings, cd and henceforth

So I am glad you managed to grasp the unspoken concept behind this post ;) (nice job on xreath, i'll admit though his zoning reminds me of velkoz at times *shudders*)

I'm like that as well. I got a good hang of almost every champ in the game after 2-3 games with them, except for some tricky champs like working out Ekko's W timings and just playing Ezreal in general.

Lol is like life, you learn from mistakes....
{{champion:16}}
I think you mean Riven if you're referencing a quote

One thing that does help learn your limits is playing more aggressively than you normally would. Sometimes you will go too deep and die, but sometimes it will work out and you can remember this in similar situations in the future. It just comes with experience though, no real way around that

A good way will be to read about the enemy champions you are facing on LOL wiki when the game is loading so you know what skills you need to watch out for. Other than that, remember to also read about the champion that you are playing because there might be something that you didn't know about your skills like for example i use to use Garen Ult on a full health champion because i didn't realise  that it deals more damage to low health targets. Another way will be to play and learn the champions you have trouble playing against and remember the cooldowns of some of their OP skills.

Generally playing a champion lots will do the trick. But honestly one thing that has helped me so much is keeping up with the LCS. I know like that's kind of another commitment in itself but honestly the shoutcasters provide you with SO MUCH knowledge every game. Knowledge that you won't get anywhere else. I don't watch every game, just my favourite teams. After that just take knowledge and apply it to Solo Q. Just always keep in mind that shit that works in LCS won't always work in SoloQ and Vise Versa.

6th sense and intuition are really just processed information from the 5 senses and memory, we evolved to have that in order to make decisions in a flash by quickly assessing the current situation against the past experiences, all within a reflex-ish manner.

Same thing with LoL, all you need is to play more.

Honestly it's based on you and your experience/playstyle with the champion.

For example, Nidalee is one of my by far best champions, and honestly i used to play her extremely aggresive and that's how i now know the full extent of my damage in most situations.

If you tend to play a champion more passively it can take a lot longer to learn the full extent of their damage, but at the same time, your less likely to lose games due to over estimating said damage.

But it comes down to you learning to see how much damage your doing against what sort of stats, and keeping that in the back of your mind.
